content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame
  SpriteSet
    floor > Immovable randomtiling=0.9 img=oryx/floor3 hidden=True
    goal  > Door color=GREEN img=oryx/doorclosed1
    key   > Immovable color=ORANGE img=oryx/key2
    sword > OrientedFlicker limit=5 singleton=True img=oryx/slash1
    movable >
      avatar  > ShootAvatar   stype=sword frameRate=8
        nokey   > img=oryx/swordman1
        withkey > color=ORANGE img=oryx/swordmankey1
      enemy >  
        monsterQuick > RandomNPC cooldown=2 cons=6 img=oryx/bat1
        monsterNormal > RandomNPC cooldown=4 cons=8 img=oryx/spider2
        monsterSlow > RandomNPC cooldown=8 cons=12 img=oryx/scorpion1
      wall > Immovable autotiling=true img=oryx/wall3
      	

  LevelMapping
    g > floor goal
    + > floor key        
    A > floor nokey
    1 > floor monsterQuick
    2 > floor monsterNormal
    3 > floor monsterSlow
    w > wall
    . > floor
    

  InteractionSet
    movable wall  > stepBack
    nokey goal    > stepBack
    goal withkey  > killSprite scoreChange=1
    enemy sword > killSprite scoreChange=2
    enemy enemy > stepBack
    avatar enemy > killSprite scoreChange=-1
    nokey key     > transformTo stype=withkey scoreChange=1 killSecond=True

  TerminationSet
    SpriteCounter stype=goal   win=True
    SpriteCounter stype=avatar win=False
This is vgdl rule in natural language:
Here’s a plain‐language breakdown of what this game is all about:

• Genre and Overall Feel
  – It’s a puzzle-action adventure played on a grid-like map.
  – You navigate a maze full of obstacles (like walls), enemies, and interactive items.
  – The game mixes exploration with combat elements since you can shoot a sword to dispatch adversaries.

• Basic Mechanics
  – The Player’s Avatar moves through the level using step-based movements.
  – The avatar can shoot a short-lived sword “flicker” (a quick burst attack) at enemies.
  – There are objects like walls that are immovable and floors that tile randomly for variety.
  – Items such as keys and doors change the state of your avatar or the level when touched.
  – Several enemy types wander around randomly, with differences in their speed and reaction times.

• Objectives
  – The main goal is to get to the door (shown as the green “goal”) to end the level.
  – However, you must have the key in your possession when you approach the door.
  – Picking up the key transforms your avatar from “nokey” to “withkey,” signaling that you’re ready to exit.

• Win and Loss Conditions
  – You win by reaching the door while holding the key. The interaction (goal withkey) triggers a level completion with a positive score change.
  – You lose if your avatar is eliminated—for example, by direct contact with enemies (which subtracts points or may be fatal over time) since the loss condition is tied to the avatar no longer being present.

• Interactions and Combat
  – If your avatar (or its representation when not carrying the key) touches a key, it transforms into the “withkey” state and you get bonus points.
  – You can also attack enemies with your sword; if a sword successfully contacts an enemy, it’s removed and gives you extra points.
  – Collisions with the door when you don’t have the key, or with walls, simply push you back instead of allowing progress.
  – Contact between the avatar and an enemy directly will dispatch the enemy too but at a point penalty, making it less desirable than an intentional sword attack.

• Suggested Overall Strategy
  – First, carefully traverse the maze to locate and collect the key. This is essential because the door (goal) only works if you’re carrying the key.
  – Avoid direct collisions with enemies—they might hurt you or reduce your score. Instead, use your sword to eliminate them when you have the chance.
  – Balance speed with caution: move quickly enough to avoid getting trapped by enemies, but be mindful of walls and other obstacles that force you to step back.
  – Once you’ve collected the key (your avatar transforms visually), plot the safest and most direct route to the door.
  – Watch out for different enemy types. Some move quickly and are more aggressive (like the “monsterQuick”), while others move slowly. Prioritize threats accordingly.
  – Remember that every collision can impact your score, so try to minimize unnecessary contact—especially by using your ranged sword attack rather than risking a direct crash with an enemy.

In essence, focus on puzzle-style navigation—first securing the key, then reaching the door—while using your combat abilities smartly to manage roaming enemies. Good luck!

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT
4: ACTION_DOWN
5: ACTION_UP

=== High Level Plan === 


**key strategy: Enforce active engagement in the floor key zone—batch-process all possible floor key pickups and concurrently deploy the sword to neutralize interfering enemy types, ensuring the avatar transforms from nokey to withkey and can progress toward the door** with **Alert**Evaluation: BAD
Feedback: Action "3" resulted in no observable change in the game state. Without any repositioning or progress toward acquiring key items or the goal, the move does not reduce risk or advance objectives, rendering it strategically ineffective.

Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
floor goal -> 'g'
floor key -> '+'
floor nokey -> 'A'
floor monsterQuick -> '1'
floor monsterNormal -> '2'
floor monsterSlow -> '3'
wall -> 'w'
floor -> '.'
goal -> '@'
key -> '#'
monsterNormal -> '$'
monsterQuick -> '%'
monsterSlow -> '&'
nokey -> '*'
sword -> 'k'
nokey sword -> 'm'

=== Current State ===
=== Original State ===
wwwwwwwwwwwww
w...%ww.....w
w..$.w......w
w.w*...&wwwww
w#w.........w
w.w..wwwwwwww
w.......w...w
w....w....w@w
wwwwwwwwwwwww

=== Rotated State (Y-axis emphasis) ===
wwwwwwwww
w...#...w
w..www..w
w....*$.w
w......%w
ww.w..www
w..w...ww
w..w.&..w
w.ww.w..w
w..w.w..w
ww.w.w..w
w@.w.w..w
wwwwwwwww
Note: In the original state, each row corresponds to horizontal (left-right) layout in the game.
In the rotated version, each row corresponds to vertical (up-down) layout.=== Map in Natural language ===
